title: How to Reduce Foot Pain from Idiopathic Peripheral Neuropathy

steps.title: Try over-the-counter pain medications.
steps.content: Try over-the-counter pain medications. If you have a mild case of peripheral neuropathy pain, you may be able to minimize it with over-the-counter pain medications, such as acetaminophen or NSAIDs like ibuprofen. Take the recommended dose that is listed on the packaging and follow the recommendations for how often to take it. [1] X Research source Talk to your doctor before taking over-the-counter pain medications if you are taking other medications as well.

steps.title: Rub on capsaicin oils and creams to minimize pain.
steps.content: Rub on capsaicin oils and creams to minimize pain. Capsaicin products contain cayenne-pepper oil, which overloads the nerves and causes pain receptors to shut down. Rub a capsaicin cream onto the painful area of your feet up to 3 times a day to relieve pain. This is a temporary but often helpful treatment. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can find capsaicin cream over-the-counter. Look for a product labeled as a 0.025% capsaicin cream, such as Zostrix. Capsaicin oils, creams, and salves can cause burning on the skin when applied. This sensation will be manageable for some but may be too uncomfortable for others to use regularly. Because capsaicin products contain pepper oil, avoid getting it in wounds, your eyes, or your mouth. Use gloves to apply it and keep the products off surfaces that you may touch later.

steps.title: Rub camphor, peppermint, or lavender oil on your feet several times a day.
steps.content: Rub camphor, peppermint, or lavender oil on your feet several times a day. While you can use straight camphor oil, experiment with rubbing in drops of camphor combined with a drop or 2 of olive oil or your favorite moisturizing lotion. You can also use the typical "vapor rub", which is usually a mixture of menthol and eucalyptus in petroleum jelly. If you like, you can also use peppermint or lavender oil for added benefits. Camphor oil will help numb your nerves, which minimizes pain. Peppermint oil helps relax your muscles. Lavender oil may help you calm down and relax, which can reduce pain. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Consult with a neurologist about pain management.
steps.content: Consult with a neurologist about pain management. An experienced neurologist is likely to understand the neurological pain you are enduring more than a typical primary care physician is. They should also know the best treatments or prescription drugs you can use to reduce your pain. A neurologist is a specialist that deals specifically with nerves and the overall nervous system.

steps.title: Take prescription meditations to help calm the nerves and pain.
steps.content: Take prescription meditations to help calm the nerves and pain. Talk to your doctor about prescription medications that can reduce your pain. Cymbalta and Lyrica are relatively new drugs that help to reduce neuropathic pain. Both require a prescription from a doctor. Older drugs like Neurontin can also be helpful but may have undesirable side effects. More traditional pain killers, such as those that contain opioids, can be extremely habit forming, so other pain killers are often prescribed first and these are only used if others do not relieve pain satisfactorily. [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Lyrica has side effects, including weight gain and dizziness, and can be habit forming if not taken as directed. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Take antidepressants to treat your pain.
steps.content: Take antidepressants to treat your pain. There has been some success with using antidepressants to treat peripheral neuropathy. These medications make chemical changes in your brain that block the nerve's ability to signal pain. Some common medications that may be prescribed include tricyclic antidepressants and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). Examples of SSRIs include Prozac, Paxil, and Zoloft. Common tricyclic antidepressants include amitriptyline and nortriptyline. These may help reduce your nerve pain. Many of these medications do have side effects, including dry mouth, dizziness, nausea, and constipation.

steps.title: Have transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) done.
steps.content: Have transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) done. This is a non-invasive treatment that uses very small electrical currents to interrupt the nerve signals that are telling the brain that you are in pain. This is a relatively new and experimental treatment that does show promise but needs more study. This treatment has mainly been used to treat peripheral neuropathy associated with diabetes. Talk to your doctor about whether this treatment is available in your area.

steps.title: Keep an eye on the health of your feet.
steps.content: Keep an eye on the health of your feet. Get a foot examination once a year from a qualified podiatrist. However, you should also check your feet yourself daily for signs of poor circulation or injuries. Some symptoms of poor circulation include excessive blisters, cuts, or calluses. [6] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Make sure you thoroughly wash your feet every day. When you dry them, pay special attention to between your toes. Talk to your podiatrist about how to check your feet, including what to be on the lookout for when checking them.

steps.title: Avoid prolonged nerve pressure.
steps.content: Avoid prolonged nerve pressure. Wear soft, loose cotton socks and padded shoes, with good arch support. Replace shoes that cause blisters. Tight shoes and socks can worsen pain and tingling, plus they can lead to sores that won't heal. [7] X Research source Also, don't sit too long or keep your legs or knees crossed. Always wear well-fitting shoes and socks. You may want to get special therapeutic shoes that will reduce pressure on your feet. Try using a semicircular hoop, which is available in medical supply stores, to keep bed covers off hot or sensitive feet while you sleep. Take care to avoid injury or infections in your feet. Don't put your body into positions or use products that reduce the circulation in your feet.

steps.title: Do foot and leg stretches.
steps.content: Do foot and leg stretches. Stretching can help your circulation and can help nerves function more reliably. Some common stretches that are used to treat peripheral neuropathy pain include: [8] X Research source Calf stretches Plantar fasciitis stretches Hamstring stretches

steps.title: Massage
steps.content: Massage your feet, or have someone massage them for you. Try giving yourself a short foot massage every night before bed or in the morning when you wake up. This will relax your feet and will give you a chance to inspect the health of your feet at the same time too. Massage helps improve circulation. It also stimulates nerves and may temporarily relieve pain.

steps.title: Treat underlying medical conditions.
steps.content: Treat underlying medical conditions. Problems with nerve function in the feet can be caused by a variety of issues, including illness, injury, infection, and inherited disorders. Not all of these causes can be treated, but many can. For instance, diabetes often leads to this condition. If you have a connected condition like diabetes, it's important to keep that condition treated effectively. [9] X Research source Some other medical conditions that may be connected to peripheral neuropathy include rheumatoid arthritis, kidney disease, HIV, shingles, and hepatitis C. [10] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Being on top of the treatment for related conditions can minimize your chance of getting peripheral neuropathy in the first place but it can also minimize pain symptoms once they appear.

steps.title: Keep your blood sugar under control.
steps.content: Keep your blood sugar under control . Uncontrolled blood sugar can worsen your pain and contribute to idiopathic peripheral neuropathy. Monitor your blood sugar daily and keep track of the readings. Eat a healthy diet by building your meals around non-starchy vegetables and lean protein. Exercise at least 30 minutes a day, and manage your stress levels with rest and relaxing activities. [11] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Take any medication that your doctor prescribes for managing your blood sugar.

steps.title: Get daily exercise.
steps.content: Get daily exercise . Ask your doctor about an exercise routine that's right for you. In most cases, this should include a combination of aerobic exercise, stretching, strength training, and balance work. Regular exercise may reduce neuropathy pain and can help control blood sugar levels, which will support nerve and circulation health. [12] X Research source If you are having trouble walking or completing daily activities, talk to your doctor about whether you should get physical therapy in addition to your regular exercise routine. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Eat healthy
steps.content: Eat healthy meals. Focus on eating low-fat meats and dairy products, as opposed to full-fat dairy and red meat. Also include lots of complex carbohydrates, fiber, fruits, vegetables, and whole grains in your diet. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Eating a healthy diet with help ensure that you get essential vitamins and minerals, which will increase your circulation, muscle, and overall health.

steps.title: Quit
steps.content: Quit smoking. Cigarette smoking can negatively affect your circulation, in addition to being horrible for your overall health. In order to quit, you should talk to your doctor about ways to stop your cravings and to adopt healthy, new habits. [15] X Research source Poor circulation increases the risk of foot problems, including peripheral neuropathy pain in the feet.

steps.title: Drink alcohol only in moderation, if at all.
steps.content: Drink alcohol only in moderation, if at all. Drinking too much alcohol can be the cause of peripheral neuropathy but it can also exacerbate symptoms that have been caused by other factors. Alcohol can cause problems with nerve communication and excessive use can cause nutritional problems that also inhibit nerve function. [16] X Research source If you cannot eliminate your alcohol consumption completely, try to keep it down to 1 or 2 drinks per day. Continuing to drink while coping with peripheral neuropathy will likely make your symptoms worse.
